Virtual Environment in Python

Purpose of virtual env is isolation. So that you can install packages that are specific to a particular project.

Installation

For newer python version >= 3.3 venv is the recommended way to manage virtual enviroment. I also comes with python standard library. On Debian/Ubuntu systems, you need to install the python3-venv package using the following command, based on python version. 

apt install python3.10-venv

Creating Virtual Environment

Creation of virtual environments is done by executing the command venv 

python3 -m venv /path/to/new/virtual/environment

Or alternatively go to your project’s directory and run venv. The second argument env is the location (subfolder inside project) to create virtual env. 

python3 -m venv env

Note: You should exclude your virtual environment directory from your version control system using .gitignore or similar.

Activating Virtual Environment

Activating a virtual environment will put the virtual environment-specific python and pip executables into your shell’s PATH. 

source env/bin/activate

You can confirm you’re in the virtual environment by checking the location of your Python interpreter: 

which python

Now you can install any package (even with specific version) with python3 -m pip install {package-name} which will be isolated to this environment only. You can see those packages by pip list

Leaving Virtual Environment

Simple command deactivate will deactive the active virtual env if you're switching to different projects or leaving this environment. 

deactivate

Sharing the Virtual Enviroment

The package version installed inside virtual enviroment is important to be shared across the team. You can create a requirements.txt file and share across teams, so that they can install the same version in their virtual env.

  1. Create requirements file 

    pip freeze > requirements.txt

  2. Install packages from requirements.txt while in virtual env. 

    pip install -r requirements.txt

Installation

Use following code in init.el file to setup org-roam. Make sure the directory ~/coding/roam-notes already exists. 

(use-package org-roam
  :ensure t
  :init
  (setq org-roam-v2-ack t)
  :custom
  (org-roam-directory "~/coding/roam-notes")
  :config
  (org-roam-setup))

Commonly used commands

  • org-roam-node-find : creates a node if it does not exist, and visits the node.
  • org-roam-capture : creates a node if it does not exist, and restores the current window configuration upon completion.
  • org-roam-insert : creates a node if it does not exist, and inserts a link to the node at point.
  • org-roam-alias-add : place cursor over the node name and run this command to add aliases.
  • org-roam-buffer-toggle : Launch an org-roam buffer alongside that tracks the node currently at point. i.e viewing backlink by opening different roam notes

We can streamline the template capture by customising own templates. While creating a new org-roam node, we'll be prompted to select the template specific to our need, e.g book, programming language etc.

Org-roam Dailies

We can capture everyday activities with org-roam-dailies. While capturing daily-note for first time, we'll be prompted to create a folder daily/ which is relative to above org-roam-directory. Following commands are helpful

  • org-roam-dailies-capture-today : Create an entry in the daily-note for today
  • org-roam-dailies-goto-today : Find the daily-note for today, creating it if necessary

Search & Replace

Search and replace is the most common operation one does in emacs buffer.

isearch-forward: command is used internally by swiper, which is bound to C-s. If not using swiper then make use of occur

isearch-backword: used to seach backword from the point, bound to C-s

isearch-forward-regexp: forward search with regex, bound to C-M-s

isearch-backword-regexp: backword search with regex, bound to C-M-r

occur: get the occurence of text line-wise and show them in a buffer, bound to M-s o Traversing in occurance of match in occur buffer will scroll the original buffer for preview. You can edit this preview by pressing e which will edit the original buffer too. You can edit using query-replace!. If want to re-edit the regex text entered in occur prompt, use M-n or M-p to circle through previously used patterns.

query-replace: Used to replace FROM string to TO string, bound to M-%. Once TO string is specified replacement will happen interactively. y for Yes, n for No and Skip, ! For replace all, u for undo prev replacement, U for undo all replacements. q to quit. Use M-n or M-p to circle through previously used patterns. Check all options with ?

query-replace-regexp: Used to replace FROM regexp to TO string, bound to C-M-%. It is also used to group the pattern match and replace with matched pattern. e.g replace var-temp with temp-var Search Pattern: \(var\)-\(temp\), TO string: \2-\1

Greatest Number

Inspired by this Leetcode Problem 321. Create Maximum Number

Given an array nums containing only digits. Create a maximum k-digit number using digits from nums. Relative ordering of digits used from the array must be preserved.

Example 1: Input: nums = [7, 9, 0, 8, 1, 7], k = 4 Output: [9, 8, 1, 7]

Example 2: Input: nums = [7, 9, 0, 8, 1, 7], k = 3 Output: [9, 8, 7]

Constraints: 1 <= nums.length <= 1e5 0 <= nums[i] <= 9 1 <= k <= nums.length

Solution

vector <int> Solve(vector <int> nums, int k) {
  // here goes your code ...
  int n = (int) nums.size();
  vector <int> ans;
  for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
    while (!ans.empty() && ans.back() < nums[i] && ((n - i) > (k - (int) ans.size()))) {
      ans.pop_back();
    }
    if ((int) ans.size() < k) {
      ans.push_back(nums[i]);
    }
  }
  return ans;
}

Subarray Sums Divisible by K

Same as this Leetcode Problem 974. Subarray Sums Divisible by K

Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return the number of non-empty subarrays that have a sum divisible by k.

Example 1: Input: nums = [4, 5, 0, -2, -3, 1], k = 5 Output: 7 Explanation: There are 7 subarrays with a sum divisible by k = 5: [4, 5, 0, -2, -3, 1], [5], [5, 0], [5, 0, -2, -3], [0], [0, -2, -3], [-2, -3]

Example 2: Input: nums = {5}, k = 9 Output: 0

Constraints: 1 <= nums.length <= 3 * 1e4 -1e4 <= nums[i] <= 1e4 2 <= k <= 1e4

Solution

int subarraysDivByK(vector<int>& nums, int k) {
  int n = (int) nums.size();
  int sum = 0, ans = 0;
  vector <int> rem(k, 0);
  rem[0] = 1;
  for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
    sum = (sum + nums[i]) % k;
    sum = (sum + k) % k;            // for ensuring positive reminder
    ans += rem[sum];
    rem[sum]++;
  }
  return ans;
}

Repeat And Missing Number

One best way is to use the input array and negate the position for which element is found. If a position is already negative, means a repeated element. If position is still positive means missing element.

Alternative way is get xor of elements from given array : {1, 2, .. . . .x, x ... ...n} / where y is missing and x appearing twice from serquecnce: {1, 2, ... ....x..y........n} / all elements from 1 … n Observation is: From above set all elements appear twice except x and y. Xoring all elements from sets will lead to xor1 = x^y value, from which using the first set bit = xor1 & ~~(xor1 - 1) So idea is to funnel above set of elements into two groups using above set beat and, xoring the elements of each group will lead to answer.

Note: Adding -1 to a number flips the bits of a number starting from right most set bit

Find inventory item with status 'A' or 'B'

db.inventory.find(
    // filter
    {
        status : {
            $in : ["A", "B"]
        }
    }
);

Find items with either status='A' or qty less than 30

$or - filter data with or condition. 

db.inventory.find(
    // filter with or conditions
    {
        $or: [
            { status: "A" },
            { qty: { $lt: 30 } }
        ]
    }
);

Find in nested document

db.inventory.find( { size: { h: 14, w: 21, uom: "cm" } } );

db.inventory.find( { "size.uom": "in" } );

Query an array

Match an array. The array has to match exactly with the document. Order of elements matter 

db.inventory.find( { tags: ["red", "blank"] } );

If order needn't be matched, then use following query. If subarray is matched, then also result is returned. $all - Match all the elements mentioned in any order. 

db.inventory.find(
    // filter
    {
        tags : {
            $all : [ "red", "blank"]
        }
    }
);

Aggregate Data ($group)

db.movies.aggregate([
  { $unwind: "$genres" },
  {
    $group: {
      _id: "$genres",
      genreCount: { $count: { } }
    }
  },
  { $sort: { "genreCount": -1 } }
]);
  • $unwind to output a document for each element in the genres array.
  • $group and the $count accumulator to count the number of occurrences of each genre. This value is stored in the genreCount field.
  • $sort to sort the resulting documents by the genreCount field in descending order.

Aggregation Operations

Total order quantity of medium size pizzas grouped by pizza name 

db.orders.aggregate([
  // Stage 1: Filter pizza order documents by pizza size
  {
    $match: { size: "medium" }
  },
  // Stage 2: Group remaining documents by pizza name and calculate total quantity
  {
    $group: {_id: "$name", totalQuantity: { $sum: "$quantity" } }
  }
]);

The following example calculates the total pizza order value and average order quantity between two dates: 

db.orders.aggregate([
  // Stage 1: Filter pizza order documents by date range
  {
    $match: {
      date : { $gte: new ISODate("2020-01-30"), $lt: new ISODate("2022-01-30") }
    }
  },
  // Stage 2: Group remaining documents by date and calculate results
  {
    $group: {
      _id: { $dateToString: { format: "%Y-%m-%d", date: "$date"} },
      totalOrderValue: { $sum: { $multiply: ["$price", "$quantity"] } },
      averageOrderQuantity: { $avg: "$quantity" }
    }
  },
  // Stage 3: Sort documents by totalOrderValue in descending order
  {
    $sort: {
      totalOrderValue: -1
    }
  }
]);

Introduction

The code blocks have import React from 'react'; for the reason of code formatting in org-babel.

Basic skeleton of react project

  • Create App by npx create-react-app my-app
  • Delete All the files inside ./src except index.js which should contain following minimal code.
  • Create index.css for styling
import React from 'react';
import ReactDom from 'react-dom';
import './index.css';

function BookList() {
  const message = 'Hello World!!';
  return (
    <React.Fragment>
      <h1> {message} </h1>
      <Book author='Mathura Tudu' price={123} />
    </React.Fragment>
  );
}

ReactDom.render(<BookList/>, document.getElementById('root'));

Passing and Receiving props

Passing props, function reference can also be passed which can be called at receiving side. e.g closeModal after timeOut of 2 seconds, call at Modal component

<Book author='Mathura Tudu' price={123} /> OR <Modal closeModal={closeModal} /> Here closeModal is a function.

Receiving props 

const Book = (props) => {
  author = props.author;
  return (
      <h1> Author name is {author} </h1>
  );
};

Destructuring

The reciever component can destructure the passed props as follows const { author, price } = props; or destructuring can happen at params as follows. children props is passed to props.children, which also can be destructured as follows. Children props are passed as <Book author='Author name'> <children> Hello There </children> </Book> 

const Book = ({ author, price, children }) => {
  return (
      <h1> Author name is {author} </h1>
  );
};

Iterate over items and pass to component

Each child in a list should have unique key. Index also could be passed when map is like books.map((book, index) => { return ( <Book key={index} author={book} />); }); But better pass some other unique id. Note : Spread operator ...books will pass its individual fields. i.e it is same as passing author, price separately and not as book object. 

import React from 'react';
function BookList() {
  const books = [{author: 'a', id: 1}, {author: 'b', id: 2}];
  return (
    <section className='booklist'>
      {
        books.map((book) => {
          return (
            <Book key={book.id} {...book} />
          );
        })
      }
    </section>
  );
}

filter is another such method for filtering out the items of interest. 

const removeId = 1;
// person with removeId will not be present in newPeople.
let newPeople = people.filter((person) => {
  return person.id != removeId;
});

Events in react

All the react events can be found Here onClick is commonly used event attached to button as follows 

import React from 'react';
function FunctionalComponent() {
  const clickHandler = (event) {
    console.log('handle on click');
  };
  const handlerWithParam = (author) => {
    console.log(author);
  };
  return (
    <>
      <button type='button' onClick={clickHandler}>simple button </button>                       // passing function reference for fn with empty params, or just event is passed
      <button type='button' onClick={() => handlerWithParam(author) }>complex onclick </button>  // use arrow function
      <h1> onClick={ () => { console.log('handle onclick'); } } </h1>
    </>
  );
}

Import and Export

Named export

Named export is as follows. Multiple exports are allowed per file. 

export function FuncName() {
  // function body
}

It can be imported as follows. The name has to match exactly 

import { FuncName } from './FuncName';
import { books} from './books';

Default Export

Default export is as follows. Only one default per file is allowed. 

const Component = () {
  // function body
};
export default Component;

Which can be imported as follows. The imported name be given any name unlike named export. 

import AnyName from './Book';

useState hook

useState is a function which returns an array of value and function controlling the value. use array destructuring to store into conventional variables as follows at top level. const [text, setText] = useState('sample title'); OR we can use React.useState('some title');

useState rerenders the component when value is changed. Note that useState it is a named export as follows. import React, { useState } from 'react';

Sometime it is important to make the update only based on previous state. Check following snippet 

const onclickIncrease = () => {
  setTimeout(() => {
    setValue((prevValue) => { return prevValue + 1; });
  }, 2000);
}

Spread operator

For copying the object we needn't copy individual fields which will be done by spread operator i.e if person = { name: "Mathura", age: 25, email: "mathura.dakshana15@gmail.com"} we can update the email and copy it into new variable as follows newPerson = { ...person, email: "new-email@gmail.com" }

Append to array can be done as follows setPeople([...people, newPerson]);

useEffect hook

By default runs after every re-render, even re-render can caused by useState Just like useState this is also a named import. useEffect is heavily used to fetch data from API when component is rendered initially. Check javascript-tutorial to see how fetch is used to fetch data from API. 

import React from 'react';
useEffect(() => {
  console.log('what is happening');
  // Api call or any other clean up
}, []);

Second param, i.e list of dependencies can be passed to useEffect, so that it'll be triggered only when those dependency value changes. [] - useEffect is invoked on first render. [value] - useEffect will run when value changes.

useEffect cleanup function

Return clean up function, which will be called before next re-render. Following snippet will prevent attaching the multiple instances of eventListener. 

const checkSize = () => { console.log('window size', window.innerWidth); };
useEffect(() => {
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkSize);
    // Return clean up function, which will be called before next re-render
    return () => {
        window.removeEventListener('resize', checkSize);
    };
});

Conditional Rendering

Following expressions shows how inline conditional rendering reduces the codebase. short-circuit evaluation and ternary operator are used.

first non-false value is returned from OR conditions e.g text || 'hello'. If text is not-empty it's value is returned, else 'hello' will be returned. last non-false value is returned from AND conditions, considering former conditions are true, otherwise nothing happens. 

import React from 'react';
const Component = () => {
  const [ isLoading, setIsLoading ] = useState(false);
  return (
    <div>
      <h1> {isLoading || 'Hello' } </h1>
      {isLoading && <h1> 'Hello' </h1> }
      <div> {isError ? (<h1> There is error </h1>) : (<h2> There is no error </h2>) } </div>
    </div>
  );
}

Controlled input

Input fields of form can be attached to the state variable as follows. While submitting we can direcly use state variables. Note onChange events can use wrapped to do some form validation. We can do more validation during handleSubmit also. 

import React from 'react';

const ControlledInputs = () => {
  const [person, setPerson] = useState({name: '', email: ''});

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault(); // for preventing the form submit and refresh automatically
    console.log(person); // use the state variable without reading from input fields.
  }
  const handleChange = (e) => {
    const name = e.target.name;
    const value = e.target.value;
    // now based on name set/validate the value
    setPerson({ ...person, [name]: value });  // using dynamic object properties.
  }

  return (
    <React.Fragment>
      <article>
        <form>
          <div>
            <label htmlFor="name">Name: </label>
            <input
              type='text'
              id='name'
              name='name'
              value={person.name}
              onChange={handleChange}
            />
          </div>

          <div>
            <label htmlFor="email">Email: </label>
            <input
              type='text'
              id='email'
              name='email'
              value={person.email}
              onChange={handleChange}
            />
          </div>

          <button type='submit' onClick={handleSubmit}> submit </submit>
        </form>
      </article>
    </React.Fragment>
  );
}

useRef hook

For handling uncontrolled input

  • preserves value
  • doesn't cause re-render, hence we can safely use useEffect without dependency array.
  • target DOM node/elements
import React from 'react';
const UserRefBasics = () => {
  const refContainer = useRef(null);
  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    // access the targetted element, which can be h1, div, or input field
    console.log(refContainer.current.value);
  }

  return (
    <>
      <form>
        <input type='text' ref={refContainer} />
        <button type='submit' onSubmit={handleSubmit}> submit </button>
      </form>
    </>
  );
}

useReducer hook

For maintaining state effectively. The steps 1 and 2 can be moved to a separate file for better code formatting. 

import React, { useState, useReducer } from 'react';
// 1. define the default state containing all state variables.
const defaultState = {
  people : [],
  isModalOpen: false,
};

// 2. define reducer function, based on action type return new state by making use of payload passed.
const reducer = (state, action) => {
  if (state.type == 'ADD_PERSON') {
    newPeople = [...state.people, action.payload];
    return {
      ...state,
      people: newPeople
    }
    throw new Error('no matching action found');
  }
}
const UseReducerComponent = () {
  const [name, setName] = useState('');  // other small states can make use of useState
  const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, defaultState);
  const addPerson = () => {
    // dispatch the action, the reducer will automatically maintain last state
    dispatch({ type: 'ADD_PERSON', peron: {name: 'Mathura', age: 23}});
  }
  // rest of all code logic ...
}

Prop Drilling

When more number of components are developed and relationship between component increases, then we'll find difficult to manage the state. Properties have to properly drilled down the components, and update may have to be reflected in the parent component. Imagine Component hierarchy BaseComponent -> ListPeople -> SinglePerson, Suppose BaseComponents have list of people, removePerson method. These properties have to be passed down to children, sometimes mid-children don't even need these props.

To solve this complexity we have

  • context-api
  • redux

useContext hook

Wrap the root or base component with context provider and pass the props which can be accessed by children. 

import React, { useContext } from 'react';
const PersonContext = React.createContext();

// 1. Provider
const RootComponent = () {
  // all code goes here ...

  return (
    <PersonContext.Provider value={ {removePerson, person} }>    // pass any value, methods
      <Children />
      <ListComponent />
    </PersonContext.Provider>
  );
}

// 2. Consumer - any children can now access those passed props
const Children = () {
  const { person, removePerson } = useContext(PersonContext);
  // use person and removePerson
}

Custom Hooks for custom useContext

We can create a global context as custom hook. Use following logic in separate file. e.g context.js 

import React, { useState, useContext } from 'react';
const AppContext = React.createContext();
const AppProvider = ({children}) => {
  const [isModalOpen, setIsModalOpen] = useState(false);  // define as many states as needed.
  const openModal = () => setIsModalOpen(true)
  return (
    <AppContext.Provider value={{ openModal }}>
      {children}
    </AppContext.Provider>
  );
}
export const useGlobalContext = () => {
  return useContext(AppContext);
};
export { AppContext, AppProvider };

Import AppProvider and wrap your app as <AppProvider> <App /> </AppProvider> Import useGlobalContext and destructure the required props.

Custom Hooks

For re-using functionality. e.g Common function to fetch data from API call Following custom hook, call it useFetch does the job of fetching products or any fetch in general. 

import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

export const useFetch = (url) => {
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [products, setProducts] = useState([]);

  const getProducts = useCallback(() => {
    const response = await fetch(url);
    const products = await reponse.json();
    setProducts(products);
    setLoading(false);
  }, [url]);

  useEffect(() => {
    getProducts();
  }, [url, getProducts]);

  return {loading, products};
}

Above custom hook can be used in other components as const { loading, products } = useFetch(url);

PropTypes

Used for validating the props passed. import as import PropTypes from 'prop-types'; e.g consider a component receiving as follows. const ProductComponent = ({image, name, price }) { }

Before exporting above component we can add following validation. 

ProductComponent.propTypes = {
  image: PropTypes.object.isRequired,
  name: PropTypes.string.isRequired,
  price: PropTypes.number.isRequired,
};

// or we can set default values as follows
ProductComponent.defaultProps = {
  image: { url: 'custom' },
  name: 'Sampoo',
  price: 25,
};

Conditional rendering can solve the issues, hence PropTypes needn't be used.

React Router

Useful single page applications, enable us to navigate to different url without page refresh Wrap your applications as follows. All matching path will be loaded. So we have to specify to be exact match and make use of Switch Install with npm install react-router-dom 

import React from 'react';
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Switch, Route, useParams } from 'react-router-dom';
import Home from './Home';

const ReactRouterComp = () => {
  return (
    <Router>
      <NavBar />

      <Switch>   // for matching URL exactly once
        <Route exact path='/'>
          <Home />
        </Route>

        <Route exact path='/people'>
          <People />
        </Route>

        <Route path='/person/:id' children={ <Person /> } > </Route>  // passing URL params

        <Route path='*'>  // custom error page when invalid URL is entered.
          <Error />
        </Route>
      </Switch>
    </Router>
  );
}

// The Child can point to URL as follows, after importing { Link} from 'react-router-dom'
const People = () => {
  const somePerson = {id: 2};
  return (
    <ul>
      <li>
        <Link to='/'> Home </Link>
      </li>
      <li>
        <Link to={`/person/${somePerson.id}`}> Learn More </Link>
      </li>
    </ul>
  );
}

// grab id passed by Route in Person comp
const Person = () => {
  const { id } = useParams();
  // make use of id
}

React.memo, useCallback, useMemo

If props don't change re-rendering is not needed. to achieve this we wrap component as follows 

import React, { useCallback } from 'react';

// 1. at top level the addToCart function will be cached, and  will not change until cart changes.
const addToCart = useCallback(() => {
  setCart(cart + 1);
}, [cart]);

// 2. down the level
const BigList = React.memo(({ product, addToCart }) => {
  // if uppler level has triggered re-render, re-rendering will not happen at this Level if product props hasn't changed.
});

// 3. When some computation is heavy and depends on few data use useMemo
const expensiveFunc = useMemo(() => {
  callExpensiveFunc(products);
}, [products]);

Reference

this keyword

The value that this store is the current execution context of the JavaScript program. In case of using this inside method of an object, this refers to that object. Inside regular function this refers to the global object which is window in browser, global in node. The call back is like a regular function inside which this refers to global object, hence make sure to pass this to callback if needed.

Map

Returns an array (can be empty). Doesn't change the size of original array (unlike filter). Uses value from original array when making new one. By default functions in js returns undefined. So make sure to return required data. 

const ages = people.map((person) => {
  return person.age;
})

Set

For storing unique values. It's analogous to set in cpp-tutorial. Set object supports methods .add(value) .delete(value) .clear() .has(value) Following code extracts all the unique categories all menu items fall into. 

const categories = new [...Set(menu.map((item) => {
  return item.category
}))]

Dynamic Object Keys

Updating the value for any key dynamically. updateState below is the required function. 

const state = { name: 'Mathura', age: 12 }
function updateState(key, value) {
  state[key] = value;
}

Filter and Find

Filter: Returns a new array, can manipulate the size of new array. Returns based on condition. Find: Returns single instance, returns first match, if no match found returns undefined. 

const teens = people.filter((person) => {   // returns array of person who are teens
  return person.age < 20
})

const ayush = people.find((person) => {     // returns a first person from list whose name is 'Ayush'
  return person.name === 'Ayush'
})

Reduce

Just like map, filter, we iterate over the array with call back function. It reduces the array to single value (which can be number, array, or object) The call back function takes two params.

  1. ('acc') - total of all calculations
  2. ('curr') - current iteration/value
const dailyTotal = staff.reduce((total, person) => {
  total += person.salary 
  return total              // always return this
}, 0);                      // second param can be any data type

Callback Function

Refer examples of map, filter, find ..etc

Callback Hell

Promises

Promise a object that returns a value that we intend to use later. So we can write asynchronous code in sequential way. A promise can be in state Pending, Rejected, Fulfilled. Calling resolve() and reject() should be decided by the developer. 

const promise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    resolve()   // can pass any data type, same goes for reject
    // reject()  
})

promise.then((data) => {
    // data sent from resolve in promise
}).catch((e) => {
    // error sent from reject in promise
})

Async-Await

Async-Await allows us to write asynchronous function in synchronous way. await is used to unwrap the promise settled, It can throw error if promise is rejected.

It can only be used if we have made the function Async. Async function always returns a promise, even if there is simply a return statement (which means auto fulfilled). We can wrap the await statements inside try-catch block 

// alternative for below is nesting the .then methods which reduces readibility
function getUser(user) {
    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        //.. do resolve, reject logic
    })
}
function getArticles(id) {
    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        //.. do resolve, reject logic
    })
}
const getData = async () => {
    try {
        const user = await getUser('math2do')                // user gets whatever is resolved inside 'getUser' function
        if (user) {
            const articles = await getArticles(user.id);
        }
    } catch(error) {
        // rejected promise                                 // error gets whatever is rejected inside either getUser or getArticle
    }
}

Fetch API call

Check complete note here - fetch fetch is used to make API call with external service.

We can use following short syntax if we are interested in the final response 

fetch(url)
  .then((resp) => resp.json())
  .then((data) => console.log(data))
  .catch((err) => console.log(err))

Async way of getting results, which is functionally same as above. 

const fetchData = async (url) => {
    try {
        const resp = await fetch(url)
        const data = resp.json()
        console.log(data)
    } catch(err) {
        console.log(err)
    }
}

Fetch error

Using .then and .catch makes the code little unreadable hence we use try, catch, async and await as below. 

const createUser = async (url = '', data = {}) => {
    try {
        const resp = await fetch(url, { method: 'POST', headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }, body: JSON.stringify(data) })
        if (!resp.ok) {
            const err = `There was some error "${resp.status} ${resp.statusText}"`;
            throw new Error(err)
        }
        const tours = resp.json()
        // use tours data...
    } catch(err) {
        console.log(err)
    }
}
createUser('https://user-service.com/create', { name: 'Mathura' });

Axios

Aggregation Framework

"$<fieldName>" refers to the name of the field in input document.

Aggregation Stages

$match $group $project $sort $count $limit $skip $out

$unwind - splits the record for reach element of specified array. Usually used in conjuction with $group, $project

Accumulators

$sum $avg $max $min

Unary operators

$type - gives the type of field

$or $lt $gt $and $multiply

One query to rule them all

db.persons.aggregate([
    // 1. $match - filter the doc, similar to find
    {
        $match: { favoriteFruite: "apple", age: { $gt: 20 } }
    },
    // $unwind - tags: ['active', 'semi-disabled', 'disabled'] - one record will be splitted to three each
    // have tags either 'active', 'semi-disabled', 'disabled'
    {
        $unwind: "$tags"
    }
    // 2. $project - select few fields, 1 - include, 0 - exclude, all zero - include all other,
    // Used for creating a new field combining other
    {
        $project: {
            _id: 0, age: 1, gender: 1, income: 1, country: 1, address: 1, "address.pincode": 0, rank: 11,
            info: {  
                eyes: "$eyesColor",
                fruit: "$favoriteFruit"
            },
            tagType: { $type: "$tags" },
            tag: "$tags"
        }
    }
    // 3. $sort by fields, 1 - asc, -1 desc
    {
        $sort: { rank: 1, age: 1, country: -1}
    }
    // $limit - compute on atleast 100 records only
    {
        $limit: 100
    }
    // 4. $group by fields
    {
        $group: {
            _id: { age: "$age", gender: "$gender" },
            count: { $sum: NumberInt(1) }, avgAge: { $avg: "$age" }
            totalIncome: { $sum: "$income"}
        }
    },
    // 5. $count - used as last stage, server side count
    {
        $count: "peopleCount"
    },
    // $out - must be the last stage, writes to other collection
    {
        $out: "aggregationResultCollection"
    }
], {
    // to override allowable 100 MB per stage
    allowDiskUse: true,
});

Window problems

int l = 0, h = 0;
int min_len = INT_MAX;
int from = -1;

while (h < len) {
  // expand h such that all chars of t are found
  while (h < len && !allFound()) {
    fres[toInt(s[h])]++;
    h++;
  }
  if (h == len && !allFound()) break;

  // shrink when all chars of t are found in window s[l:h)
  while (l < h && allFound()) {
    if (h - l < min_len) {
      min_len = h - l;
      from = l;
    }
    fres[toInt(s[l])]--;
    l++;
  }
 }

Always used in context with goroutine. Create with make function as ch := make(chan int). In unbuffered channel only one message can be present at a time. for val := range ch {       // make sure producer closes the channel

for {

select statement without default case is blocking until msg comes to any channel. Then it again goes back to blocking. create signal channel: var doneCh = make(chan struct{}) write to signal channel: doneCh <- struct{}{} 

for {

Final keyword in java

Method Overriding

For runtime polymorphism. The method must have the same name and definition as in parent class. Child class must be inheriting parent class. main function can't be overriden since it is static method.

Method Hiding for static method

If a subclass defines a static method with the same signature as a static method in the super class, in such a case, the method in the subclass hides the one in the superclass. It happens because static methods are resolved at compile time. If parent type variable holds the child variable, then child method (in case of overriden) is called. Else parent method(in case of method hiding, i.e the variable type), is called.

Static keyword in java

Associated to memory management.

static variable: Common property of all objects, Hence it is class property. Gets memory only once in the class area at the time of class loading.

static method : Static method belongs to the class rather than the object of a class. Can access/modify static data member.

static block : Used to initialize the static data member. It is executed before the main method at the time of class loading.

static nested class : It can access static data members of the outer class, including private.

Polymorphism = poly + morph

Static polymorphism : using method overloading. e.g add function for int and float Runtime polymorphism : using method overriding.

Static and Dynamic binding

Variable is assigned a type as follows.

Static binding (early binding) : The object is determined at compiled time. int x = 10 or Dog d = new Dog()

Dynamic binding (late binding) : The object is determined at run-time. Animal a = new Dog()

Abstraction is a concept/way of showing only essential things to the user and hides the internal details abstract class (0-100% abstraction) : same as normal classes except it has keyword abstract. The class must be inherited and abstract methods must be implemented. interface (100% abstraction) : can have static variable. Inheriting class must provide implementations.

Inner Class

It can access all the members of the outer class, including private data members and methods.

Reference

NPTEL Lecture by PPD, IIT Kharagpur

File Organisation

Database -> Collection of Files -> Sequence of Records -> Sequence of Fields

Indexing

Index File consists of search-key : pointer Ordered Indices - Search keys are stored in sorted order Hash Indices - Search keys are distrbuted across buckets using hash functions

Index Evaluation Metrics Access time, Insertion time, Deletion time, Space overhead

Primary Indexing/Clustered Indexing An index whose search key specifies the sequential order of files. Dense Index: where index record appears on every search-key value Sparse Index: contains index record for only some search-key value. Applicable when records are sequentially ordered on search-key

Seconday Indexing/Non-clustering Index An index whose search key specifies an order different from sequential order of files. They have to be dense.

Multilevel Indexing

If primary index doesn't fit in memory, then access becomes expensive, since fething from disk is costly. Solution: Treat primary index as sequential file and construct sparse index on it.

  • Outer Index - sparse index of primary index. If this is also too large, add another level and so on.
  • Inner Index - the primary index file.

Data Structure for Indexing

Balanced Binary Search Trees Good for in memory operations. Works well for small volume of data. Don't scale for external data structures.

2-3-4 Trees All leaves at same depth. All data is kept in sorted order. Every node is a 2-node, 3-node or 4-node and holds 1, 2 or 3 nodes repectively.

B+-Tree B+-Tree Index Files is a generalisation of 2-3-4 Tree. These are alternative to indexed sequential files.

  • All paths from root to leaf are of same length
  • Each non-leaf node contains between ceil(n/2) and n children (atleast half full), because sometimes split into half is required. e.g in 2-3-4 trees, if insertion is required at node with 3 children.
  • Leaf node has between ceil((n-1)/2) and n-1 values or records pointers.
  • Non-leaf forms a sparse Indices.
  • The search becomes very effective with disk access of atmost level = LOGn/2(K)

Node is generally the same size as disk block, typically 4KB, And hence n is typically around 100. Ideas is n shouldn't be too large for it to be contained in disk block, otherwise partial read will happen.

B-Tree Index Files Allows seach-key values to appear only once. This search key in non-leaf appears only in one node. Hence additional pointer field is required. This is a optimisation of B+-Tree. Seach can end happen in non-leaf as well. But has high depth since fan-out is reduced. Hence B+-Tree is more used.

Issues If a record moves all the secondary indices that store record pointers have to be updated. Solution: Use primary-index search key instead of record pointer in secondary index.

Hashing Schemes

Bucket - Unit of storage containing one or more records (typically a disk block) So in hash file organisation the bucket is directly obtained by hash function. For a search-key having small range of values we can use this bitmap indexes.

Index Design in SQL

create index b-index on branch(branch_name);
drop index b-index;

int pid = fork();

Reference

Youtube Videos by Brijesh Gupta Offical Documentation Offical Kafka Documentation

Introduction

Kafka is a distributed Message Streaming Platform that usess publish and subscribe mechanism to stream records.

Benefits

  • Scalable - Horozontal Scaling is done by adding new brokers to the cluster without downtime.
  • Fault Tolerance - ditributed in nature so, in case of broker failure, other brokers can continue.
  • Durable - Retention time can be set to persist the message on disk.
  • Performace - Kafka has high throughput for both publishing and subscribing messages.
  • No data Loss - Due to replicas
  • Zero downtime - When more clusters are to be added.

Why use Kafka over SQS and SNS? Multiple consumers (consumer group) are supported in Kafka, whereas in SQS one consumer can subscribe to each queue. So SQS is pull based and point to point. SNS offers publish/subscribe like kafka but there is no retention.

  • Kakfa is highly scalable and supports high payload.

Key Terminologies

Broker - Software processes which maintain the published messages. They maintain the consumer offsets to ensure proper delivery of messages.

Zookeeper - Monitors kafka cluster and co-ordinate with each broker. Helps in electing the Controller within kafka clusters. Group of zookeepers are called Zookeeper Ensemble. There is one zookeeper leader elected. No of zookeepers should be odd. e.g 3, 5 ..

Topic - A Stream of messages belonging to a particular category is called a topic. It is analogous to table in database. The unique identifier of a topic is its name.

Partition - Topics are splitted into partitions. Messages within partition are ordered and immutable. Each message in a partition has unique id called offset. The partitions can be distributed across different kafka brokers.

Replica - Replicas are backup of a partition. They are not read or write data while main partions are alive. They are used to prevent data loss. These are also distributed across brokers.

  • Partions are distributed to brokers in round-robin fashion.
  • A publisher publishes its message to partitions in round-robin fashion. (It's configurable to send to specific parition)

Producer - Producers are the applications which write/publish data to the topics within a cluster using Producing APIs. Producers can produce data on topic level or even specific partition of the topic.

Consumer - Consumers also can consume data at topic level or partition level. Consumers are associated to exactly one Consumer Group (Related Consumers)

Topic

After kafka and zookeepes are installed, following commands are useful to get information about topic.

Create a Topic

replication-factor param can't me more than kafka broker. 

bin/kafka-topics.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --create --topic myTopic --partitions 1 --replication-factor 1

Alter Topic Partition

Partitions can only be increased. 

bin/kafka-topics.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --alter --topic myTopic --partitions 2

Partition Reassignment

Use cases. All below are handled by controller node.

  1. Move partitions across brokers
  2. Selectively move replicas of a partition to specific set of brokers
  3. Increasing the replication factor as in above step.

Commands

The sample-file.json should be as follows. The partitions of myTopic have leaders which can be changed with following commands. 

{
  "topics" : [{"topic": "myTopic"}],
  "version": 1
}

Following command is to change the change the leaders of partitions (for topic myTopic) to have leaders from brokers. 

#Generate - 
bin/kafka-reassign-partitions.sh --zookeeper localhost:2181 --topics-to-move-json-file {sample-file.json} --broker-list "2,3" --generate
#Execute
bin/kafka-reassign-partitions.sh --zookeeper localhost:2181 --reassignment-json-file {file-generated-above.json} --execute
#Verify
bin/kafka-reassign-partitions.sh --zookeeper localhost:2181 --reassignment-json-file {file-generated-above.json} --verify

Similarly in the generated file, replication broker can also be changed and execute to take the effect.

List Topics

bin/kafka-topics.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --list

Describe a Topic

bin/kafka-topics.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --describe --topic myTopic

Console Producer

bin/kafka-console-producer.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --topic myTopic

Console Consumer

We can add the group name at end of following command with param --group myConsumerGroup 

bin/kafka-console-consumer.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --topic myTopic --from-beginning

List Consumer Groups

bin/kafka-consumer-group.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --list

Describe Consumer Group

From the output of above get a group and analyse using 

bin/kafka-consumer-group.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --describe --group {group-name}

Kafka automatically creates a topic named __consumer_offsets for tracking the consumer details

Setup Zookeeper

Offical Documentation Download the zookeeper archive from apache and extract it. ./bin/zkServer.sh is the required file to run which can take configuration file zoo.cfg (create manually) stored at ./conf/ directory. 

tickTime: 2000                       #the no. of miliseconds of each tick
initLimit: 10                        #the no. of ticks initial synchronisation can take  
syncLimit: 5                         #the no. of ticks that can pass between sending a request and getting an acknowledgement
dataDir: /temp/zookeeper-1           #the directory where the snapshot is stored. Change it if multiple zookeepers are setup. Create all these directories
clientPort: 2181                     #the port clients will connect to. Change it for running different zookeepers. e.g 2182 for second zookeeper
maxClientCnxns: 60
4lw.commands.whitelist: *

#1, 2, 3 are identifier
#create a file myid in /temp/zookeeper-1 with content 1, similarly with 2 and 3, with command 'echo 1 >> /temp/zookeeper-1/myid'
server.1: localhost:2788:3788        #first port is used for communications among zookeepers, second port is for electing leader.
server.2: localhost:2888:3888 
server.3: localhost:2988:3988

Check status

The status of zookeepers running at client ports can be checked by following command. It also tells us if zookeeper is follower or leader. 

echo stat | nc localhost 2181

Setup Kafka Cluster

Like above create three copies of downloaded kafka archive and extract into three folders. e.g node-1, node-2, node-3 You can edit the conf/server.properties file with following keys. 

broker.id: 1                                                             #2 and 3 for setting 3 brokers
listeners: PLAINTEXT://localhost:9092                                    #change port with multiple broker setup
log.dirs: /tmp/kafka-logs-1                                              #2 and 3 for setting 3 brokers
zookeeper.connect: localhost:2181,localhost:2182,localhost:2183          #the client port configured in above zookeeper setup

Start the kafka broker with following command 

bin/kafka-server-start.sh config/server.properties

Check if the zookeeper is using these brokers created. Second command tells about controller broker 

echo dump | nc localhost 2181 | grep brokers

echo dump | nc localhost 2181                         #for checking controller broker

Internals of Topics, Partitions and Replication

bin/kafka-topics.sh --bootstrap-server localhost:9092,localhost:9093,localhost:9094 --create --topic myTopic --partitions 3 --replication-factor 2

Describe command returns following result. Parition-0 Parition-0 Leader-1 Replicas-1,2 ISR-1,2

  • Partition-0 is present in broker-1,2
  • Leader-1 means Read and Write to this partition will be coordinated by broker-1
  • Partion-0 has replicas in broker-1,2
  • The ISR (In Sync Replica) are present in broker-1,2. It can also be only in broker-1 if broker-2 is down.

Parition-1 Parition-1 Leader-2 Replicas-2,3 ISR-2,3

Parition-2 Parition-2 Leader-3 Replicas-3,1 ISR-3,1

States of Partition when we create a Topic

Controller broker manages the state of partition and replicas anf for performing administrative tasks like reassigning partitions.

  1. NonExistentPartition - Partition was never created or was deleted.
  2. NewPartition - In this state partition should have replica assigned to it, but no leader/isr yet
  3. OnlinePartition - Once a leader is elected for the partition it is in this online state
  4. OfflinePartition - If after above state, the leader partition dies, then partition moves to offline state.

Similarly replicas also have states - NonExistentReplica, NewReplica, OnlineReplica, OfflineReplica

Offsets in Kafka

Producer.send() - Sends the messages in round-robin fashion to parition (This is by default) Offset is a property of partition (an identifier of record). Offsets are maintained for each consumer group. Consider producer has to send 10 messages {a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, i, j} Below topic consists of 3 partitions and messages are distributed in round-robin by default.

partition (row)/offset(col) 0 1 3 4 5 6
Partition-0 a d g j    
Partition-1 b e h      
Partition-2 c f i      
  1. Log-end offset - Offset of the last message written to a log/partition
  2. Current offset - Pointer to the last record that kafka has already sent to a consumer group in the most recent poll. (Consumer.poll())
  3. Commited offset - Marking an offset as consumed is called commited offset. (Consumer.commit())

Messages sent by producer 

{
  "key": " <for sending to specific partition, same keys will be sent to same partition>",
  "payload": "Message body"x
}

Internally above message is stored in filesystem with more metadata as shown below. 

{
  "key": " <for sending to specific partition, same keys will be sent to same partition>",
  "payload": "Message body",
  "topic": "myTopic",
  "partition": "1",
  "offset": "3",
  "timestamp": "2022-03-01 12:12:00" 
}

Messages read by consumer Consumer.poll() - Request for new messages Consumer.commit() - Acknowledgement that message is read/consumer. There are three such type, 1-autoCommit(), 2-manualCommit()

max.poll.record - x, configuration for reading x records at a time.

Internals of Consumer Group

Consumer group is a logical entity (some microservice) which mainly provides parallel processing/Scalable message consumption to consumer clients. There shouldn't be duplicate of message sent to consumers of same consumer group.

Consumer Group Rebalancing : The process of re-distributing partitions to consumers within the same consumer group is known as Consumer Group Rebalancing.

p0 ---> c1 <---p2 p0 --->c1 c2<--p2 | | p1 p1

1 consumer in a group 2 consumers in a group (Same partition will not send message to multiple consumers, hence prevents duplicate)

Note: Creating more consumers will sit idle, since they can't subscribe to any partition.

Group Coordinator

Brokers from cluster are assigned as group coordinator for handling a subset of consumer groups.

Group Leader

First consumer to join the consumer group is elected as the Group Leader. It has the list of active memebers in that consumer gorup. It executes group Rebalances.

When a consumer joins these API calls happen: FindCoordinator -> JoinGroup -> SyncGroup . Each consumer periodically sends Hearbeat request to Group Coordinator to keep its session alive

Kafka Producer Configs

bootstrap.server - List of host/port pairs used by Producer to establish initial connection with kafka clusters. The list should be of form host1:port1,host2:port2,host3:port3 The list needn't contain all host:port pairs. One pair is enough to make connections with rest. client.id - Producer is given id string ssed to trace the requests for debugging purpose. key.serializer - Serializer class, Is a process of converting an object into stream of bytes. (defaulted to byte array serializer) value.serializer - Same as above but used for serializing value(payload) (defaulted to byte array serializer) connections.max.idle.ms - Close idle connections after the no. of miliseconds specified by this config. (Default 540000ms=9mins)

ACKS - When producer sends record, it waits for the acknowledgement from cluster. Acks=0 - The producer will not wait for any acknowledgment from server. There is no guarantee that cluster has recieved the message. Acks=1 - (Default) The leader will write record to its local log, but will respond without awaiting full acks from followers. In this case the Leader should be very healthy. Acks=-1 - This is the strongest available guarantee. This means the leader will wait for full set of in-sync replicas to acknowledge. This is same as acks=all

compression.type - Used to compress the message. Kafka supports none, gzip, snap, lz4, zstd batch.size - The message are sent to cluster in batches of this size to be sent to same replica. buffer.memory - buffer memory are where batches are stored in memory of the producer. linger.ms - Rather than immediately sending out a record, producer will wait for upto given delay(linger.ms) to allow other records to be sent so that sends can be batched together. max.request.size - maximum size of request in byte.

All above properties can be overriden in file config/producer.properties

Kafka Consumer Configs

bootstrap.server - Same as producer configs. Check above client.id - An id string to pass to the server when making a request. key.deserializer - Reverse of serializer. Converting bytes into objects group.id - The unique string that identifies the group that this consumer belongs to. fetch.minimum.byte - The minimum amount of data the server should return for a fetch request. The server should accumulate this much data, then only it'll return. heartbeat.interval.ms - The consumer sends health status to group coordinator. Value should be lower than session.timeout.ms given below, typically shoud be > 1/3rd of session.timeout.ms session.timeout.ms - Used to detect client failures. After this time if no heartbeat is recieved by group coordinator will assume it dead and rebalances occur. max.partition.fetch.bytes - Maximum amount of data per-partition the server will return. fetch.max.bytes - The maximum amount the server should return for a fetch request.

Rebase

Git rebase is used to make the commit history linear by replaying the commits onto some base. This is done in several stages as per the commits. If a feature branch which was originated from master has now grown too much, we can squash the commits so that replay doesn't happen too many times while rebasing with master. 

# start rebasing master
git rebase master

# above command will start the rebase session which can be aborted anytime
git rebase --abort

# if there is conflict with some commit the conflict needs to be resolved and added with git add
# then continue to change the same commit if you wish
git rebase --continue

# if a commit can be entirely skipped to
git rebase --skip

Interactive rebasing will first allow you do edit one file, where you can add commands about what to do with those commits when their turn comes in the replay. Then save the file and rebase will continue as per the commands you supplied.

body:
Introduction

Reference: Youtube: Cybersecurity Shandy. This note is a direct translation of youtube video. For more check the bash manual

  • https://flokoe.github.io/bash-hackers-wiki/
  • https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/bash.html
  • https://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/index.html

Shell means the programme which provides command-line interface for interacting with operating system. Bash happens to be one of the most commonly used shell programme. It is also a default shell in many linux distro. Bash scripting means writting a sequence of commands which are interpreted by bash shell. The code snippets used in this tutorial are specific to bash shell and may not run in other shell programme, like ksh, zsh etc.

Check shell details using: 

# $0 inside script has different meaning, It means the script file, like scrip.sh
echo $0
bash --version

Expansions

Bash provides some handy shortcuts called expansions. This is to ease the process of writting too many code. Excute the code block using org-babel-confirm-evaluate(C-c C-c) 

echo ~
echo ~-

# interpolation within a range
# following creates file name same as below fruits
# beware that items should be comma delimited and no space should be added
touch {apple,banana,cherry,durian}

# following are like looping over the range
echo {1..10}
# one leading zero is enough to fill width
echo {01..10}
echo {a..z}
echo {A..Z}

# or backwards
echo {z..a..2}

# third part is interval
echo {1..10..2}
echo {a..z..2}

# file_1, file_10, file_2.... The file ordering is not good
touch file_{1..1000}

# file_001, file_002 ... here files are lexicographically easy to see
touch file_{01..100}

Code expansion in above looks like a for loop is run in the range. So the nested for loop can be emulated by simply providing two ranges. Below command outputs like: 01_a, 01_b, 01_c .......02_a, 02_b.... 

touch {01..10}_{a..z}

# count no of files created
ls -1 | wc -l

Pipes

Pipes takes the result of one command and pipes into the another for further processing. The command, more is used to view details page by page and less is probably more usefull since it allows scrolling in both direction. 

echo {01..1000} | more
echo {01..1000} | less
ls | more

Redirection

We can redirect the standard input, output or error.The symbol, < is used to redirec input, whereas symbol > is used to redirect output. Symbol 1> and 2> are used for redirecting standard output and error respectively. Both can be redirected to a same file too using &>. 

./sol < input
./sol < input > output

cp -v * ../some-other 1> ../sucess.txt 2> ../error.txt
cp -v * ../some-other &> logs.txt

# when you don't care about output, send them to vacuum
echo "bye..bye!" > /dev/null

Grep

grep is a search utility. It allows us to search a pattern from the file. More of this can be found in linux-command .Grep is used along with other cmd tools like awk, sed, cut which provides the text processing on filtered result. 

# always colour the output by setting following in shell startup script
export GREP_OPTIONS='--colour=auto'

# Here awk is used to print 12th word from each line
grep -i break-in auth.log | awk {'print $12'}

ping -c 1 example.com | grep 'bytes from' | cut -d = -f 4

Scripting

First line of script contains what is referred to as Hashbang OR Shebang which is nothing but #!, followed by path to the shell executable. So, the first line for bash script is #!/bin/bash. Bash doesn't mind indentation or extra white space. Run the script using command: bash script.sh or simply ./script.sh if user has executable permission. The permission can be given using: chmod +x script.sh

If path to script is added to the path variable, then it can be run anyware using script.sh 

#!/bin/bash
echo 'This is from bash script file'

# These are comments
# One more comment

Echo

Text can be displayed with command echo 

greeting=Hello

# without single quote, some special chars needs to be escaped
echo $greeting World \(planet\)

# everything comes out literlly, $var is not resolved
echo '$greeting World (planet)'

# $var are variables, you can escape as \$var
# So with double quote, variables can be easily inserted.
echo "$greeting World (planet)"

#empty lines
echo
echo

Variables

As with any other programming language bash supports variables. Variables name start with a letter and subsequent alphanumeric characters. 

a=Hello
b="Good Morning"
c=16
echo "$a, $b, I have $c apples."

Use declare to add attributes 

# d is an integer
declare -i d=123

# read only, basically a const variable
declare -r e=456

There are builtin variables too like $HOME, $PWD, $MACHTYPE (returns machine type), $HOSTNAME (system name), $USER (username), $BASH_VERSION, $SECONDS (no. of seconds bash session have been running since login). You can echo these variables to see their content.

Result of one command can be stored into a variable as follows: 

d=$(pwd)
echo $d

Arithmetic Operations

The expression must be wrapped inside double round brackets with leading dollar symbol as follows: $(( expression )) 

a=10
b=3
echo $((a ** b))  # exponentiation
echo $((a * b))
echo $((a / b))   # integral division
echo $(echo a/b | bc -l) # floating point division 

echo $((a % b))
echo $((a + b))
echo $((a - b))

echo $((a--))
echo $((a++))
echo $((a+=4))  # other operators could be used too.

Comparison Operations

Logical comparisons are very important to make decisions while writting a script. The sytax is as follows. The extra space shown between brackets is to prevent org-mode from treating it like a link. The returned value is has unusual meaning. 1 mean False, 0 means True. The space between brackets and operands and between operands and operator is mandatory as in given examples. Operators are: <, >, <=, >=, ==, !=

[ [ expression ] ] 

# spacing is mandatory
[[ $a < $b ]]
# print return value
echo $?

[[ "string-a" == "string-b" ]]
echo $?

For working with integers the same operators are given different names: -lt, -gt, -le, -ge, -eq, -ne 

[[ $a -lt $b ]]
echo $?

Logical Operations

Logicall operations are used join boolean expressions to get eventual True or False. It has binary operators, && (and), || (or) and unary operators ! (negation), -z (is null), -n (is not null) 

# empty string is considered null
[[ -z "" ]]
echo $?  # prints 0

[[ -z "" || 1 < 2 ]]
echo $?  # prints 0

String Operations

string concatenation can be done with c=$a$b, but there can't be space between $a and $b. Various string operations are shown below. 

# concatenate
a="Hello"
b="World"
c=$a$b
echo $c

# with spaces
c="$a something $b"
echo $c

# length of string
echo ${#c}

# substring starting from nth index, here n=3
echo ${c:3}

# substring of some length from index n, here n=3, substring length=5
echo ${c:3:5}

# last n characters, here n=4
echo ${c: -4}
# First 3 of last 4 chars
echo ${c: -4:3}

# replace first occurence of substr 'banana' with 'apple' from string 'fruits'
echo ${fruits/banana/apple}

Function params are cought into $1, $2 … and so on. Or range over $@ which contains all the arguments passed to the function.

    echo "Hello World $1, $2"
}

Inputs and Flags

To make your function more interactive, often it is important make function to accept inputs from user. These arguments are similar to how a bash functions process the arguments passed to it.

$0 : is the script name $1 : is the first argument, $2 captures second argument and so on. $@ : captures all the arguments from \(1... =\)#= : contains the number of arguments from $1..

Call the programme as bash script.sh arg1 arg2 

# prints the first param
echo $1

Flags are the most important input parameters which can be passed in any order. Lets say we need username and password to run the script. Following script if executed as bash script.sh -u math2do -p user_123, will store the param inside some variables for further processing. The flags can be in any order. 

# here u and p are expected to be passed
while getopts u:p: option; do
    case $option in
        u) user=$OPTARG;;
        p) pass=$OPTARG;;
    esac
done

# make some optional params, a and b are optional so by convention they are kept at end
# all params are optional, so not null check must happen for compulsory flags
# unexpected params are manually  handled, below code shows bash can be informed about such unexpeted param
while getopts u:p:ab option; do
    case $option in
        u) user=$OPTARG;;
        p) pass=$OPTARG;;
        a) a=$OPTARG;;
        b) b=$OPTARG;;
        ?) echo "Unexpected param"  
    esac
done

# adding colon in beginning tells the bash that unknown params have come
while getopts :u:p:ab option; do
    case $option in
        u) user=$OPTARG;;
        p) pass=$OPTARG;;
        a) a=$OPTARG;;
        b) b=$OPTARG;;
        ?) echo "Unexpected param"
    esac
done

Interactive inputs 

echo "What is your name?"
read name

echo "Welcome $name"

# silent reading of password
echo "Password:"
read -s pass

# same line input
echo -p "Your favourite animal" animal

# give the user menu to choose from numbered list, user needs to choose the number
select animal in "cat" "dog" "bird" "fish"
do
    echo "You selected $animal"
    break
done

# wire selection with case
select option in "cat" "dog" "bird" "fish"
do
    case $option in
        cat) echo "You like cats";;
        dog) echo "You like dogs";;
        cat) echo "You like birds";;
        cat) echo "You like fishes";;
        *) echo "I don't know what you like";;  # comma is automatically getting inserted.
    esac

    # if you don't put break, you've keep selecting animals from list
    break
done

If some inputs needs to be provided by user then validate the input. Check if flag is passed or not as shown: 

read -p "Your favourite animal" animal
while [[ -z "$animal" ]]; do
    read -p "I need an answer" animal
done

Sometime if user doesn't provide input you can assume some default values. 

read -p "Your favourite animal [cat]" animal
if [[ -z "$animal" ]]; then
    animal="cat"
fi
echo "$animal is selected"

    • Dirty Read

body:
Introduction

Most popular database system satisfies the property called ACID, which stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation And Durability respectively. We'll focus on Isolation, also known as Transaction Isolation.

The most secure way to execute transactions is to run the trasactions one by one, sequentially. But with this approach we'll lose the capability of concurrency. Some trasactions may take long time, and may be we could have run a concurrent transaction so that we could fetch results fastly. But allowing concurrent trasactions can lead to various inconsistencies described below.

Read Phenomena

Dirty Read

When a transaction reads a data that is partially modified by another uncommited transaction.

Non-Repeatable Read

When a transaction reads the the same row twice, and it gets different result because another transaction commited some changes in between.

Phantom Read

When a transaction re-executes query, the different set of rows satisfies the query because another concurrent transaction affected some rows.

Isolation Levels

Levels of Isolations is the strictness applied to transactions. At highest Isolation level, we expect non of above read phenomena to occur. Following is list from high to low

  1. Serializable
  2. Repeatable Read
  3. Read Commited
  4. Read Uncommited

Following table shows the relationship between Isolation Levels and Read Phenonmena.

  Serializable Repeatable Read Read Commited Read Uncommited
Dirty Read No No No Yes
Non-Repeatable Read No No Yes Yes
Phantom Read No No Yes Yes

body:
React Server Components

Server components are evaluated or computed in server. This is called SSR (Server Side Rendering). The resultant HTML code is shipped to client. Only the Client Components remain intact and bundler ships them to client as it is. Server Components helps us with computing HTML with needed data embedded. We needn't use hook like useEffect to fetch data from client side.

In Next.js, all components are Server Components by default. To make a component Client Component, we have to use use-client directive at the top of the file.

Note: Don't confuse with directive use-server, with Server Components. This directive is used for Server Actions.

Server Actions

Server Actions are async functions which are executed at server. These async functions can be invoked from client as handler for onClick, form action or can be called inside a function in client component. They can be thought of as API call to server. Server Actions should be used with useTransition() hook to know the pending status of the action. 

"use client";

import {updateName} from './actions';

function UpdateName() {
  const [name, setName] = useState('');
  const [error, setError] = useState(null);

  const [isPending, startTransition] = useTransition();

  const submitAction = async () => {
    startTransition(async () => {
      const {error} = await updateName(name);
      if (!error) {
        setError(error);
      } else {
        setName('');
      }
    })
  }

  return (
    <form action={submitAction}>
      <input type="text" name="name" disabled={isPending}/>
      {state.error && <span>Failed: {state.error}</span>}
    </form>
  )
}

The Server Actions should be put into a single file for readability, however, you can put async function at the top of Client Component. Just put directive, use-server at the beginning of the function. 

"use client";
async function doSomething() {
  'use server'
  // do something
}

function SomeClientComponent() {
  return (
    <button onClick={doSomething}>click me</button>
  )
};

Another way is to use another hook called useActionState which also tells us about the pending state and final result of the action 

"use client";

import {updateName} from './actions';

function UpdateName() {
  //  const [, submitAction] = useActionState(updateName, null, `/name/update`); // for redirection upon successfull action
  const [state, submitAction, isPending] = useActionState(updateName, {error: null});

  return (
    <form action={submitAction}>
      <input type="text" name="name" disabled={isPending}/>
      {state.error && <span>Failed: {state.error}</span>}
    </form>
  );

Suspense

This is react component which loads a temporary, sort of loading view, before actual components are rendered. This temporary component is fallback component. Suspense can be nested, so we can think of them as suspense boundaries. Use Suspense with hook useTransition to prevent fallback of nearest parent from showing, as in most part we want children to show the loading state. So in child component, put state updator like setAge(20) inside the startTransition. 

<Suspense fallback={<Loading />}>
    <DelayedComponent />
</Suspense>
